content: I and Abdal created this course at Stanford to teach Lean 4: https://web.stanford.edu/class/cs99/
I think that @David Renshaw has some work on chess (re "not done before, e.g. chess")

Kevin Buzzard said:

I think that David Renshaw has some work on chess (re "not done before, like chess")

sorry that was not phrased well. I was using chess as an example of a board game formalized in Lean
Chess.lean is still incomplete and could use a major overwrite. So if someone is interested in pursuing that, I think it could plausibly be a nice project.
At ICERM, @Kim Morrison pointed out that there was also a branch#chess in mathlib
Leni Aniva has marked this topic as resolved.
Was it hard to convince the admin to offer it ? and how popular is it ?

Nadim Farhat said:

Was it hard to convince the admin to offer it ? and how popular is it ?

I just saw this message. It was not hard to convince the admin. Many students were interested.
However, after teaching it I realized my pace was a bit too fast, and the course could be slowed down or supplemented by more examples.
